statement.p:
For each sentence below, decide whether it is an atomic statement, a molecular statement, or not a statement at all.
Customers must wear shoes.
The customers wore shoes.
The customers wore shoes and they wore socks.

li.p: This is not a statement. It is an imperative sentence, but is not either true or false. It doesn't matter that this might actually be the rule or not. Note that The rule is that all customers must wear shoes is a statement.
This is a statement, as it is either true or false. It is an atomic statement because it cannot be divided into smaller statements.
This is again a statement, but this time it is molecular. In fact, it is a conjunction, as we can write it as The customers wore shoes and the customers wore socks.

statement.p:
For each sentence below, decide whether it is an atomic statement, a molecular statement, or not a statement at all.
Customers must wear shoes.
?
atomic statement
molecular statement
not a statement
The customers wore shoes.
?
atomic statement
molecular statement
not a statement
The customers wore shoes and they wore socks.
?
atomic statement
molecular statement
not a statement

li.p: This is not a statement. It is an imperative sentence, but is not either true or false. It doesnt matter that this might actually be the rule or not. Note that The rule is that all customers must wear shoes is a statement.
This is a statement, as it is either true or false. It is an atomic statement because it cannot be divided into smaller statements.
This is again a statement, but this time it is molecular. In fact, it is a conjunction, as we can write it as The customers wore shoes and the customers wore socks.

statement.p:
Use the table to decide whether the following statements are true or false.
\forall x \exists y P(x,y).
\forall y \exists x P(x,y).
\exists x \forall y P(x,y).
\exists y \forall x P(x,y).

li.p: \forall x \exists y P(x,y) is false because when x = 4, there is no y which makes P(4,y) true.
\forall y \exists x P(x,y) is true. No matter what y is (i.e., no matter what column we are in) there is some x for which P(x,y) is true. In fact, we can always take x to be 3.
\exists x \forall y P(x,y) is true. In particular x=3 is such a number, so that no matter what y is, P(x,y) is true.
\exists y \forall x P(x,y) is false. In fact, no matter what y (column) we look at, there is always some x (row) which makes P(x,y) false.

statement.p:
Use the table to decide whether the following statements are true or false.
\forall x \exists y P(x,y)\text{.}
?
True
False
Not enough information
\forall y \exists x P(x,y)\text{.}
?
True
False
Not enough information
\exists x \forall y P(x,y)\text{.}
?
True
False
Not enough information
\exists y \forall x P(x,y)\text{.}
?
True
False
Not enough information

li.p: \forall x \exists y P(x,y) is false because when x = 4\text{,} there is no y which makes P(4,y) true.
\forall y \exists x P(x,y) is true. No matter what y is (i.e., no matter what column we are in) there is some x for which P(x,y) is true. In fact, we can always take x to be 3\text{.}
\exists x \forall y P(x,y) is true. In particular x=3 is such a number, so that no matter what y is, P(x,y) is true.
\exists y \forall x P(x,y) is false. In fact, no matter what y (column) we look at, there is always some x (row) which makes P(x,y) false.

statement.p:
Let A = \{1, 4, 9\} and B = \{1, 3, 6, 10\}. Find each of the following sets.
A \cup B.
A \cap B.
A \setminus B.
B \setminus A.
statement.instruction: Your answers should include the curly braces

statement.p:
Find the least element of each of the following sets, if there is one.
\{n \in \N \st n^2 - 3 \ge 2\}.
\{n \ge 0 \st n^2 - 5 \in \N\}.
\{n^2+1 \st n \in \N\}.
\{n \in \N \st n = k^2 + 1 \text{ for some } k \in \N\}.
statement.instruction: If there is no least element, enter none.

li.p: This is the set \{3, 4, 5, \ldots \} since we need each element to be a natural number whose square is at least three more than 2. Since 3^2 - 3 = 6 but 2^2 - 3 = 1 we see that the first such natural number is 3.

Here we don't specify that n must be a whole number at first, but the condition we place on it, that n^2 - 5 \in \N does guarantee this (since square a non-integer always gives a non-integer, as does subtracting 5 from a non-integer). So in fact, we get the same set as we did in the previous part, and the smallest non-negative number for which n^2 - 5 is a natural numbers is 3.
Note that if we didn't specify n \ge 0 then any integer less than -3 would also be in the set, so there would not be a least element.

This is the set \{1, 2, 5, 10, \ldots\}, namely the set of numbers that are the result of squaring and adding 1 to a natural number. (0^2 + 1 = 1, 1^2 + 1 = 2, 2^2 + 1 = 5 and so on.) Thus the least element of the set is 1.

Now we are looking for natural numbers that are equal to taking some natural number, squaring it and adding 1. That is, \{1, 2, 5, 10, \ldots\}, the same set as the previous part. So again, the least element is 1.

This is the set \{3, 4, 5, \ldots \} since we need each element to be a natural number whose square is at least three more than 2. Since 3^2 - 3 = 6 but 2^2 - 3 = 1 we see that the first such natural number is 3.

Here we dont specify that n must be a whole number at first, but the condition we place on it, that n^2 - 5 \in \N does guarantee this (since square a non-integer always gives a non-integer, as does subtracting 5 from a non-integer). So in fact, we get the same set as we did in the previous part, and the smallest non-negative number for which n^2 - 5 is a natural numbers is 3.
Note that if we didnt specify n \ge 0 then any integer less than -3 would also be in the set, so there would not be a least element.

This is the set \{1, 2, 5, 10, \ldots\}\text{,} namely the set of numbers that are the result of squaring and adding 1 to a natural number. (0^2 + 1 = 1\text{,} 1^2 + 1 = 2\text{,} 2^2 + 1 = 5 and so on.) Thus the least element of the set is 1.

Now we are looking for natural numbers that are equal to taking some natural number, squaring it and adding 1. That is, \{1, 2, 5, 10, \ldots\}\text{,} the same set as the previous part. So again, the least element is 1.

statement.p:
Find the following cardinalities:
|A| when A = \{4,5,6,\ldots,37\}.
|A| when A = \{x \in \Z \st -2 \le x \le 100\}.
|A \cap B| when A = \{x \in \N \st x \le 20\} and B = \{x \in \N \st x \mbox{ is prime} \}.

li.p: 34. Note that 37-4 = 33, but this calculation would not include 4 itself.
103. Again, you could compute this by 100-(-2)+1, or simply count: 100 numbers from 1 through 100, plus -2, -1, and 0.
8. There are 8 primes not greater than 20: \{2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19\}.
34. Note that 37-4 = 33\text{,} but this calculation would not include 4 itself.
103. Again, you could compute this by 100-(-2)+1\text{,} or simply count: 100 numbers from 1 through 100, plus -2, -1, and 0.
8. There are 8 primes not greater than 20: \{2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19\}\text{.}

statement.p: Find a set of largest possible size that is a subset of both \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\} and \{2, 4, 6, 8,10\}.
Find a set of largest possible size that is a subset of both \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\} and \{2, 4, 6, 8,10\}\text{.}
Find a set of smallest possible size that has both \{1,2,3,4,5\} and \{2,4,6,8,10\} as subsets.
Find a set of smallest possible size that has both \{1,2,3,4,5\} and \{2,4,6,8,10\} as subsets.
Let A = \{n \in \N \st 20 \le n \lt 50\} and B = \{n \in \N \st 10 \lt n \le 30\}. Suppose C is a set such that C \subseteq A and C \subseteq B. What is the largest possible cardinality of C?

Let A = \{n \in \N \st 20 \le n \lt 50\} and B = \{n \in \N \st 10 \lt n \le 30\}\text{.} Suppose C is a set such that C \subseteq A and C \subseteq B\text{.} What is the largest possible cardinality of C\text{?}
Let A = \{1,2,3,4,5\} and B = \{2, 3, 4\}. How many sets C have the property that C \subseteq A and B \subseteq C.

hint.p: You should be able to write all of them out. Don't forget A and B, which are also candidates for C.

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,3,4,5\} and B = \{2, 3, 4\}\text{.} How many sets C have the property that C \subseteq A and B \subseteq C\text{.}

hint.p: You should be able to write all of them out. Dont forget A and B\text{,} which are also candidates for C\text{.}

solution.p: There will be exactly 4 such sets: \{2, 3, 4\}\text{,} \{1,2,3,4\}\text{,} \{2,3,4,5\} and \{1,2,3,4,5\}\text{.}

statement.p:
Let A = \{1,2,3,4,5\}, B = \{3,4,5,6,7\}, and C = \{2,3,5\}.
Find A \cap B.
Find A \cup B.
Find A \setminus B.
Find A \cap \overline{(B \cup C)}.

Let A = \{x \in \N \st 4 \le x \lt 12\} and B = \{x \in \N \st x \text{ is even}\}.
Find A \cap B.
Find A \setminus B.

li.p: A \cap B will be the set of natural numbers that are both at least 4 and less than 12, and even. That is, A \cap B = \{x \in \N \st 4\le x \lt 12 \wedge x \text{ is even}\} = \{4, 6, 8, 10\}.
A \setminus B is the set of all elements that are in A but not B. So this is \{x \in \N \st 4 \le x \lt 12 \wedge x \text{ is odd}\} = \{5,7,9,11\}.
Note this is the same set as A \cap \overline{B}.
A \cap B will be the set of natural numbers that are both at least 4 and less than 12, and even. That is, A \cap B = \{x \in \N \st 4\le x \lt 12 \wedge x \text{ is even}\} = \{4, 6, 8, 10\}\text{.}
A \setminus B is the set of all elements that are in A but not B\text{.} So this is \{x \in \N \st 4 \le x \lt 12 \wedge x \text{ is odd}\} = \{5,7,9,11\}\text{.}
Note this is the same set as A \cap \overline{B}\text{.}

statement.p:
Determine whether each molecular statement below is true or false, or whether it is impossible to determine. Assume you do not know what my favorite number is (but you do know that 13 is prime).
If 13 is prime, then 13 is my favorite number.
If 13 is my favorite number, then 13 is prime.
If 13 is not prime, then 13 is my favorite number.
13 is my favorite number or 13 is prime.
13 is my favorite number and 13 is prime.
7 is my favorite number and 13 is not prime.
13 is my favorite number or 13 is not my favorite number.

li.p: It is impossible to tell. The hypothesis of the implication is true. Thus the implication will be true if the conclusion is true (if 13 is my favorite number) and false otherwise.
This is true, no matter whether 13 is my favorite number or not. Any implication with a true conclusion is true.
This is true, again, no matter whether 13 is my favorite number or not. Any implication with a false hypothesis is true.
For a disjunction to be true, we just need one or the other (or both) of the parts to be true. Thus this is a true statement.
We cannot tell. The statement would be true if 13 is my favorite number, and false if not (since a conjunction needs both parts to be true to be true).
This is definitely false. 13 is prime, so its negation (13 is not prime) is false. At least one part of the conjunction is false, so the whole statement is false.
This is true. Either 13 is my favorite number or it is not, but whichever it is, at least one part of the disjunction is true, so the whole statement is true.

li.p: It is impossible to tell. The hypothesis of the implication is true. Thus the implication will be true if the conclusion is true (if 13 is my favorite number) and false otherwise.
This is true, no matter whether 13 is my favorite number or not. Any implication with a true conclusion is true.
This is true, again, no matter whether 13 is my favorite number or not. Any implication with a false hypothesis is true.
For a disjunction to be true, we just need one or the other (or both) of the parts to be true. Thus this is a true statement.
We cannot tell. The statement would be true if 13 is my favorite number, and false if not (since a conjunction needs both parts to be true to be true).
This is definitely false. 13 is prime, so its negation (13 is not prime) is false. At least one part of the conjunction is false, so the whole statement is false.
This is true. Either 13 is my favorite number or it is not, but whichever it is, at least one part of the disjunction is true, so the whole statement is true.

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,\ldots, 10\}. How many subsets of A contain exactly one element (i.e., how many singleton subsets are there)?
How many doubleton subsets (containing exactly two elements) are there?

hint.p: Write these out, or at least start to and look for a pattern.

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,\ldots, 10\}\text{.} How many subsets of A contain exactly one element (i.e., how many singleton subsets are there)?
How many doubleton subsets (containing exactly two elements) are there?

hint.p: Write these out, or at least start to and look for a pattern.

statement.p:
Let A = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}. Suppose B is a set with |B| = 5.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cup B|? Explain.
\le |A \cup B| \le
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cap B|? Explain.
\le |A \cap B| \le
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \times B|? Explain.
\le |A \times B| \le

Let A = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}\text{.} Suppose B is a set with |B| = 5\text{.}
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cup B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cap B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \times B|\text{?} Explain.

Consider the function f:\{1,2,3,4\} \to \{1,2,3,4\} given by
f(n) = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4}{4 \amp 1 \amp 3 \amp 4} .
Find f(1).
Find an element n in the domain such that f(n) = 1.
Find an element n of the domain such that f(n) = n.
Find an element of the codomain that is not in the range.

li.p: f(1) = 4, since 4 is the number below 1 in the two-line notation.
Such an n is n= 2, since f(2) = 1. Note that 2 is above a 1 in the notation.
n = 4 has this property. We say that 4 is a fixed point of f. Not all functions have such a point.
Such an element is 2 (in fact, that is the only element in the codomain that is not in the range). In other words, 2 is not the image of any element under f; nothing is sent to 2.

statement.p: Consider the function f:\{1,2,3,4\} \to \{1,2,3,4\} given by

li.p: Find f(1)\text{.}
Find an element n in the domain such that f(n) = 1\text{.}
Find an element n of the domain such that f(n) = n\text{.}
Find an element of the codomain that is not in the range.
f(1) = 4\text{,} since 4 is the number below 1 in the two-line notation.
Such an n is n= 2\text{,} since f(2) = 1\text{.} Note that 2 is above a 1 in the notation.
n = 4 has this property. We say that 4 is a fixed point of f\text{.} Not all functions have such a point.
Such an element is 2 (in fact, that is the only element in the codomain that is not in the range). In other words, 2 is not the image of any element under f\text{;} nothing is sent to 2.

statement.p:
The following functions all have \{1,2,3,4,5\} as both their domain and codomain. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{3 \amp 3 \amp 3 \amp 3 \amp 3}.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{2 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp 5 \amp 4}.
f(x) = 6 - x.
f(x) = \begin{cases} x/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is even} \\ (x+1)/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is odd}\end{cases}.

li.p: This is neither injective nor surjective. It is not injective because more than one element from the domain has 3 as its image. It is not surjective because there are elements of the codomain (1, 2, 4, and 5) that are not images of anything from the domain.
This is a bijection. Every element in the codomain is the image of exactly one element of the domain.
This is a bijection. Note that we can write this function in two line notation as f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{5 \amp 4 \amp 3 \amp 2 \amp 1}.

In two line notation, this function is f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 3}. From this we can quickly see it is neither injective (for example, 1 is the image of both 1 and 2) nor surjective (for example, 4 is not the image of anything).

statement.p:
The following functions all have \{1,2,3,4,5\} as both their domain and codomain. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{3 \amp 3 \amp 3 \amp 3 \amp 3}\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{2 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp 5 \amp 4}\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither
f(x) = 6 - x\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither
f(x) = \begin{cases} x/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is even} \\ (x+1)/2 \amp \text{ if } x \text{ is odd}\end{cases}\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither

li.p: This is neither injective nor surjective. It is not injective because more than one element from the domain has 3 as its image. It is not surjective because there are elements of the codomain (1, 2, 4, and 5) that are not images of anything from the domain.
This is a bijection. Every element in the codomain is the image of exactly one element of the domain.
This is a bijection. Note that we can write this function in two line notation as f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{5 \amp 4 \amp 3 \amp 2 \amp 1}\text{.}

In two line notation, this function is f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \amp 3}\text{.} From this we can quickly see it is neither injective (for example, 1 is the image of both 1 and 2) nor surjective (for example, 4 is not the image of anything).

statement.p:
The following functions all have domain \{1,2,3,4,5\} and codomain \{1,2,3\}. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 1}.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp 2}.
f(x) = \begin{cases} x \amp \text{ if } x \le 3 \\ x-3 \amp \text{ if } x \gt 3\end{cases}.

The following functions all have domain \{1,2,3,4,5\} and codomain \{1,2,3\}\text{.} For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 1}\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 5}{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 1 \amp 2}\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither
f(x) = \begin{cases} x \amp \text{ if } x \le 3 \\ x-3 \amp \text{ if } x \gt 3\end{cases}\text{.}
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither

The following functions all have domain \{1,2,3,4\} and codomain \{1,2,3,4,5\}. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4}{1 \amp 2 \amp 5 \amp 4}.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4}{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 2}.
f(x) gives the number of letters in the English word for the number x. For example, f(1) = 3 since one contains three letters.

The following functions all have domain \{1,2,3,4\} and codomain \{1,2,3,4,5\}\text{.} For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4}{1 \amp 2 \amp 5 \amp 4}\text{.}

Neither

?

Bijective
Neither
f(x) gives the number of letters in the English word for the number x\text{.} For example, f(1) = 3 since one contains three letters.
?
Injective
Surjective
Bijective
Neither
Write out all functions f: \{1,2,3\} \to \{a,b\} (using two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are injective?
How many are surjective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 8 functions, including 6 surjective and zero injective funtions.

statement.p: Write out all functions f: \{1,2,3\} \to \{a,b\} (using two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are injective?
How many are surjective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 8 functions, including 6 surjective and zero injective funtions.

statement.p: Write out all functions f: \{1,2\} \to \{a,b,c\} (in two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are injective?
How many are surjective?
How many are bijective?
Write out all functions f: \{1,2\} \to \{a,b,c\} (in two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are injective?
How many are surjective?
How many are bijective?
Consider the function f:\N \to \N given recursively by f(0) = 1 and f(n+1) = 2\cdot f(n). Find f(10).

solution.p: f(10) = 1024. To find f(10), we need to know f(9), for which we need f(8), and so on. So build up from f(0) = 1. Then f(1) = 2, f(2) = 4, f(3) = 8, . In fact, it looks like a closed formula for f is f(n) = 2^n. Later we will see how to prove this is correct.

statement.p: Consider the function f:\N \to \N given recursively by f(0) = 1 and f(n+1) = 2\cdot f(n)\text{.} Find f(10)\text{.}

solution.p: f(10) = 1024\text{.} To find f(10)\text{,} we need to know f(9)\text{,} for which we need f(8)\text{,} and so on. So build up from f(0) = 1\text{.} Then f(1) = 2\text{,} f(2) = 4\text{,} f(3) = 8\text{,} .... In fact, it looks like a closed formula for f is f(n) = 2^n\text{.} Later we will see how to prove this is correct.

statement.p:
Suppose f:\N \to \N satisfies the recurrence f(n+1) = f(n) + 3. Note that this is not enough information to define the function, since we don't have an initial condition. For each of the initial conditions below, find the value of f(5).
f(0) = 0.
f(5) =
f(0) = 1.
f(5) =
f(0) = 2.
f(5) =
f(0) = 100.
f(5) =

solution.p:
For each case, you must use the recurrence to find f(1), f(2) f(5). But notice each time you just add three to the previous. We do this 5 times.
f(5) = 15.
f(5) = 16.
f(5) = 17.
f(5) = 115.

statement.p:
In my safe is a sheet of paper with two shapes drawn on it in colored crayon. One is a square, and the other is a triangle. Each shape is drawn in a single color. Suppose you believe me when I tell you that if the square is blue, then the triangle is green. What do you therefore know about the truth value of the following statements?
The square and the triangle are both blue.
The square and the triangle are both green.
If the triangle is not green, then the square is not blue.
If the triangle is green, then the square is blue.
The square is not blue or the triangle is green.

solution.p:
The main thing to realize is that we don't know the colors of these two shapes, but we do know that we are in one of three cases: We could have a blue square and green triangle. We could have a square that was not blue but a green triangle. Or we could have a square that was not blue and a triangle that was not green. The case in which the square is blue but the triangle is not green cannot occur, as that would make the statement false.
This must be false. In fact, this is the negation of the original implication.
This might be true or might be false.
True. This is the contrapositive of the original statement, which is logically equivalent to it.
We do not know. This is the converse of the original statement. In particular, if the square is not blue but the triangle is green, then the original statement is true but the converse is false.
True. This is logically equivalent to the original statement.

statement.p:
In my safe is a sheet of paper with two shapes drawn on it in colored crayon. One is a square, and the other is a triangle. Each shape is drawn in a single color. Suppose you believe me when I tell you that if the square is blue, then the triangle is green. What do you therefore know about the truth value of the following statements?
The square and the triangle are both blue.
?
True
False
Not enough information
The square and the triangle are both green.
?
True
False
Not enough information
If the triangle is not green, then the square is not blue.
?
True
False
Not enough information
If the triangle is green, then the square is blue.
?
True
False
Not enough information
The square is not blue or the triangle is green.
?
True
False
Not enough information

solution.p:
The main thing to realize is that we dont know the colors of these two shapes, but we do know that we are in one of three cases: We could have a blue square and green triangle. We could have a square that was not blue but a green triangle. Or we could have a square that was not blue and a triangle that was not green. The case in which the square is blue but the triangle is not green cannot occur, as that would make the statement false.
This must be false. In fact, this is the negation of the original implication.
This might be true or might be false.
True. This is the contrapositive of the original statement, which is logically equivalent to it.
We do not know. This is the converse of the original statement. In particular, if the square is not blue but the triangle is green, then the original statement is true but the converse is false.
True. This is logically equivalent to the original statement.

statement.p:
Let X = \{n \in \N \st 0 \le n \le 999\} be the set of all numbers with three or fewer digits. Define the function f:X \to \N by f(abc) = a+b+c, where a, b, and c are the digits of the number in X (write numbers less than 100 with leading 0's to make them three digits). For example, f(253) = 2 + 5 + 3 = 10.
Let A = \{n \in X \st 113 \le x \le 122\}. Find f(A).
Find f\inv(\{1,2\})
Find f\inv(3).
Find f\inv(28).
Is f injective? Explain.
Is f surjective? Explain.

Again, suppose the statement if the square is blue, then the triangle is green is true. This time however, assume the converse is false. Classify each statement below as true or false (if possible).
The square is blue if and only if the triangle is green.
The square is blue if and only if the triangle is not green.
The square is blue.
The triangle is green.

solution.p:
The only way for an implication P\imp Q to be true but its converse to be false is for Q to be true and P to be false. Thus:
False.
True.
False.
True.

statement.p:
Again, suppose the statement if the square is blue, then the triangle is green is true. This time however, assume the converse is false. Classify each statement below as true or false (if possible).
The square is blue if and only if the triangle is green.

True
False
Not enough information
The square is blue if and only if the triangle is not green.
?
True
False
Not enough information
The square is blue.
?
True
False
Not enough information
The triangle is green.
?
True
False
Not enough information

solution.p:
The only way for an implication P\imp Q to be true but its converse to be false is for Q to be true and P to be false. Thus:
False.
True.
False.
True.

statement.p:
Consider the statement, If you will give me a cow, then I will give you magic beans. Decide whether each statement below is the converse, the contrapositive, or neither.
If you will give me a cow, then I will not give you magic beans.
If I will not give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow.
If I will give you magic beans, then you will give me a cow.
If you will not give me a cow, then I will not give you magic beans.
You will give me a cow and I will not give you magic beans.
If I will give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow.

solution.p: The converse is If I will give you magic beans, then you will give me a cow. The contrapositive is If I will not give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow. All the other statements are neither the converse nor contrapositive.

statement.p:

solution.p: The converse is If I will give you magic beans, then you will give me a cow. The contrapositive is If I will not give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow. All the other statements are neither the converse nor contrapositive.

statement.p:
You have discovered an old paper on graph theory that discusses the viscosity of a graph (which for all you know, is something completely made up by the author). A theorem in the paper claims that if a graph satisfies condition (V), then the graph is viscous. Which of the following are equivalent ways of stating this claim? Which are equivalent to the converse of the claim?
A graph is viscous only if it satisfies condition (V).
A graph is viscous if it satisfies condition (V).
For a graph to be viscous, it is necessary that it satisfies condition (V).
For a graph to be viscous, it is sufficient for it to satisfy condition (V).
Satisfying condition (V) is a sufficient condition for a graph to be viscous.
Satisfying condition (V) is a necessary condition for a graph to be viscous.
Every viscous graph satisfies condition (V).
Only viscous graphs satisfy condition (V).

li.p: Equivalent to the converse.
Equivalent to the original theorem.
Equivalent to the converse.
Equivalent to the original theorem.
Equivalent to the original theorem.
Equivalent to the converse.
Equivalent to the converse.
Equivalent to the original theorem.

statement.p:
Let P(x) be the predicate, 3x+1 is even.
Is P(5) true or false?
What, if anything, can you conclude about \exists x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)?
What, if anything, can you conclude about \forall x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)?

solution.p: P(5) is the statement 3\cdot 5 + 1 is even, which is true. Thus the statement \exists x P(x) is true (for example, 5 is such an x). However, we cannot tell anything about \forall x P(x) since we do not know the truth value of P(x) for all elements of the domain of discourse. In this case, \forall x P(x) happens to be false (since P(4) is false, for example).

statement.p:
Let P(x) be the predicate, 3x+1 is even.
Is P(5) true or false?
?
True
False
Neither (not a statement)
What, if anything, can you conclude about \exists x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)\text{?}
What, if anything, can you conclude about \forall x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)\text{?}

solution.p: P(5) is the statement 3\cdot 5 + 1 is even, which is true. Thus the statement \exists x P(x) is true (for example, 5 is such an x). However, we cannot tell anything about \forall x P(x) since we do not know the truth value of P(x) for all elements of the domain of discourse. In this case, \forall x P(x) happens to be false (since P(4) is false, for example).

statement.p:
Let P(x) be the predicate, 4x+1 is even.
Is P(5) true or false?
What, if anything, can you conclude about \exists x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)?
What, if anything, can you conclude about \forall x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)?

Let P(x) be the predicate, 4x+1 is even.
Is P(5) true or false?
?
True
False
Not enough information
What, if anything, can you conclude about \exists x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)\text{?}
What, if anything, can you conclude about \forall x P(x) from the truth value of P(5)\text{?}

For a given predicate P(x), you might believe that the statements \forall x P(x) or \exists x P(x) are either true or false. How would you decide if you were correct in each case? You have four choices: you could give an example of an element n in the domain for which P(n) is true or for which P(n) if false, or you could argue that no matter what n is, P(n) is true or is false.
What would you need to do to prove \forall x P(x) is true?
What would you need to do to prove \forall x P(x) is false?
What would you need to do to prove \exists x P(x) is true?
What would you need to do to prove \exists x P(x) is false?

li.p: The claim that \forall x P(x) means that P(n) is true no matter what n you consider in the domain of discourse. Thus the only way to prove that \forall x P(x) is true is to check or otherwise argue that P(n) is true for all n in the domain.
To prove \forall x P(x) is false all you need is one example of an element in the domain for which P(n) is false. This is often called a counterexample.
We are simply claiming that there is some element n in the domain of discourse for which P(n) is true. If you can find one such element, you have verified the claim.

Here we are claiming that no element we find will make P(n) true. The only way to be sure of this is to verify that every element of the domain makes P(n) false. Note that the level of proof needed for this statement is the same as to prove that \forall x P(x) is true.

statement.p:
For a given predicate P(x)\text{,} you might believe that the statements \forall x P(x) or \exists x P(x) are either true or false. How would you decide if you were correct in each case? You have four choices: you could give an example of an element n in the domain for which P(n) is true or for which P(n) if false, or you could argue that no matter what n is, P(n) is true or is false.
What would you need to do to prove \forall x P(x) is true?
What would you need to do to prove \forall x P(x) is false?
What would you need to do to prove \exists x P(x) is true?
What would you need to do to prove \exists x P(x) is false?

li.p: The claim that \forall x P(x) means that P(n) is true no matter what n you consider in the domain of discourse. Thus the only way to prove that \forall x P(x) is true is to check or otherwise argue that P(n) is true for all n in the domain.
To prove \forall x P(x) is false all you need is one example of an element in the domain for which P(n) is false. This is often called a counterexample.
We are simply claiming that there is some element n in the domain of discourse for which P(n) is true. If you can find one such element, you have verified the claim.

Here we are claiming that no element we find will make P(n) true. The only way to be sure of this is to verify that every element of the domain makes P(n) false. Note that the level of proof needed for this statement is the same as to prove that \forall x P(x) is true.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2019-08-15T11:55:32-06:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(B.1.4.14) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PCCmacros.pl", "parserRadioButtons.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $foralltrue = RadioButtons( ['Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is true.','Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is false.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is true.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is false.'], 'Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is true.', # correct answer ); $forallfalse = RadioButtons( ['Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is true.','Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is false.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is true.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is false.'], 'Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is false.', # correct answer ); $existstrue = RadioButtons( ['Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is true.','Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is false.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is true.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is false.'], 'Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is true.', # correct answer ); $existsfalse = RadioButtons( ['Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is true.','Give an example of an element \(n\) in the domain for which \(P(n)\) is false.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is true.','Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is false.'], 'Show for every element \(n\) in the domain, that \(P(n)\) is false.', # correct answer );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML For a given predicate [`P(x)\text{,}`] you might believe that the statements [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] or [`\exists x P(x)`] are either true or false. How would you decide if you were correct in each case? You have four choices: you could give an example of an element [`n`] in the domain for which [`P(n)`] is true or for which [`P(n)`] if false, or you could argue that no matter what [`n`] is, [`P(n)`] is true or is false. a. What would you need to do to prove [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] is true?
[@KeyboardInstructions(q?[_]{$foralltrue}{5}?)@]**
a. What would you need to do to prove [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] is false?
[@KeyboardInstructions(q?[_]{$forallfalse}{5}?)@]**
a. What would you need to do to prove [`\exists x P(x)`] is true?
[@KeyboardInstructions(q?[_]{$existstrue}{5}?)@]**
a. What would you need to do to prove [`\exists x P(x)`] is false?
[@KeyboardInstructions(q?[_]{$existsfalse}{5}?)@]**
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. The claim that [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] means that [`P(n)`] is true no matter what [`n`] you consider in the domain of discourse. Thus the only way to prove that [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] is true is to check or otherwise argue that [`P(n)`] is true for all [`n`] in the domain.
a. To prove [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] is false all you need is one example of an element in the domain for which [`P(n)`] is false. This is often called a counterexample.
a. We are simply claiming that there is some element [`n`] in the domain of discourse for which [`P(n)`] is true. If you can find one such element, you have verified the claim.
a. Here we are claiming that no element we find will make [`P(n)`] true. The only way to be sure of this is to verify that _every_ element of the domain makes [`P(n)`] false. Note that the level of proof needed for this statement is the same as to prove that [`\def\d{\displaystyle}\def\course{Math 228}\newcommand{\f}[1]{\mathfrak #1}\forall x P(x)`] is true.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();
